articles.headline: Geithner Suggests That Strauss-Kahn Step Aside
articles.snippet: Dominique Strauss-Kahn has not left the International Monetary Fund, but jockeying has begun to replace him.
articles.abstract: Dominique Strauss-Kahn has not left the International Monetary Fund, but jockeying has begun to replace him.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — As Dominique Strauss-Kahn was left to spend another day behind bars in New York, a pack of would-be successors wasted little time Tuesday maneuvering for his job as managing director of the International Monetary Fund, one of the most powerful positions in global finance, and U.S. officials openly suggested that he step down.

articles.headline: Some See Rise Ahead for Dollar
articles.snippet: For the better part of the past decade, and particularly in the past few months, the dollar has been the weakling of the foreign exchange world. That may be starting to change.
articles.abstract: For the better part of the past decade, and particularly in the past few months, the dollar has been the weakling of the foreign exchange world. That may be starting to change.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Could the long dollar slide be over?

articles.headline: Church Report Cites Social Tumult in Priest Scandals
articles.snippet: A study commissioned by American Roman Catholic bishops says abuse occurred because priests who were poorly prepared landed in the midst of the turmoil of the 1960s and 1970s.
articles.abstract: A study commissioned by American Roman Catholic bishops says abuse occurred because priests who were poorly prepared landed in the midst of the turmoil of the 1960s and 1970s.
articles.lead_paragraph: A five-year study commissioned by the nation’s Roman Catholic bishops to provide a definitive answer to what caused the church’s sexual abuse crisis has concluded that neither the all-male celibate priesthood nor homosexuality were to blame.

articles.headline: In Consumer Behavior, Signs of Gas Price Pinch
articles.snippet: As gasoline prices stay high, Americans are turning to public transit and choosing homes closer to work.
articles.abstract: As gasoline prices stay high, Americans are turning to public transit and choosing homes closer to work.
articles.lead_paragraph: High gasoline prices have not derailed the economic recovery, but that’s small comfort to Loraine Greene. A customer relations manager in the Hudson Valley of New York, Ms. Greene spent the weekend packing up to move to a rental house much closer to work.
articles.byline: By Motoko Rich and Stephanie Clifford

articles.headline: In Japan Reactor Failings, Danger Signs for the U.S.
articles.snippet: Vents that American officials said would prevent devastating explosions at nuclear plants in the United States were put to the test in Japan and failed.
articles.abstract: Vents that American officials said would prevent devastating explosions at nuclear plants in the United States were put to the test in Japan and failed.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Emergency vents that American officials have said would prevent devastating hydrogen explosions at nuclear plants in the United States were put to the test in Japan — and failed to work, according to experts and officials with the company that operates the crippled Fukushima Daiichi plant.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi, Keith Bradsher and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: Chemical Suspected in Cancer Is in Baby Products
articles.snippet: A chemical suspected of being a carcinogen that was removed from children’s pajamas decades ago is prevalent in baby’s products made with polyurethane foam, new research shows.
articles.abstract: A chemical suspected of being a carcinogen that was removed from children’s pajamas decades ago is prevalent in baby’s products made with polyurethane foam, new research shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than 30 years after chemical flame retardants were removed from children’s pajamas because they were suspected of being carcinogens, new research into flame retardants shows that one of the chemicals is prevalent in baby’s products made with polyurethane foam, including nursing pillows, car seats and highchairs.

articles.headline: PC Makers Are Seeing a Slowdown
articles.snippet: Despite a slowly recovering economy, consumers have been eager to buy tablet computers, which cuts into the PC market.
articles.abstract: Despite a slowly recovering economy, consumers have been eager to buy tablet computers, which cuts into the PC market.
articles.byline: By VERNE G. KOPYTOFFand LAURIE J. FLYNN

articles.headline: For Buyers of Web Start-Ups, Quest to Corral Young Talent
articles.snippet: Some companies want talent so badly, they buy start-ups for their employees and then jettison the products.
articles.abstract: Some companies want talent so badly, they buy start-ups for their employees and then jettison the products.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Sam Lessin sold his Web start-up to Facebook for millions last year, and Facebook promptly shut it down. All Facebook wanted was Mr. Lessin.

articles.headline: Atop I.M.F., Contradiction and Energy
articles.snippet: Dominique Strauss-Kahn’s financial acumen is widely praised at the International Monetary Fund, but disturbing sexual charges mar his reputation.
articles.abstract: Dominique Strauss-Kahn’s financial acumen is widely praised at the International Monetary Fund, but disturbing sexual charges mar his reputation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Artful politician that he is, Dominique Strauss-Kahn has a keen sense for not just his strengths but also his potential weaknesses — though few would be quite as blunt in saying so.
articles.byline: By Landon Thomas Jr. and Steven Erlanger
